title: Jose Mourinho and Graeme Souness are wrong
text:

I was almost seething after the game about the comments from Jose Mourinho and Graeme Souness that Liverpool struggle against teams defending deep.

I’ve never heard so much tripe in my life.

Liverpool are European champions and have lost one of their last 47 league games.

They’re unbeaten in 18, they have won the Super Cup and Champions League and 95 per cent of teams who go to Anfield will play defensively.

So there’s not one statistic to back up what they were saying.

United on the up?

(Image: Getty Images)

Manchester United played on the front foot and looked cohesive in their 1-1 draw with Liverpool on Sunday.

And the most impressive thing about Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s men was the fact they maintained a high standard of discipline and tempo for 70 or 75 minutes.

Tackles went in, they closed down spaces — it was a solid 8/10 performance and we’ve not been able to say that of them many times this season.

So that performance has to be the flag in the sand for the campaign and if they play like that week in, week out they can finish in the top four.

If not they will be sixth or seventh at least, and maybe even scraping into the top 10.

Alli must unleash nasty side

(Image: Getty Images)

After Dele Alli made his first Premier League start of the season, it’s time to give him the kick up the backside he needs.

Long-time readers will know he’s one of my favourite players in our game when he’s on song and I do like the fact he’s a nice lad with that big grin.

But that can only take you so far in the game and he now has to get his head down and forget the clowning around if he doesn’t want to be overtaken at Tottenham and with England.

If he even added one per cent of the nastiness of a Roy Keane or Graeme Souness to his game it would be the start to him going on to fulfil a potential which could see him become the best midfielder of his type in Europe.

This time two years ago, we’d have been talking about him being indispensable for club and country but that isn’t the case for either anymore.

Grealish deserves England chance

No player was more influential for his team over the weekend than Aston Villa’s Jack Grealish.

I sent him a message after the last England games saying there’s nothing for him to fear in terms of his rivals for the national team.

James Maddison is probably ahead of him in the queue and Mason Mount as well.

But if you put Grealish in any environment at club level or for his country he would make things happen for those ahead of him, and I’d have him in the next Three Lions squad all day long.

Collywobbler

Lo and behold, Hearts are trying to discover if a fan racially abused Alfredo Morelos, Haringey and Yeovil staged a walk-off and their FA Cup tie was abandoned and Bristol City are investigating alleged racist chants against Luton fans.

Yet I don’t hear the same outcry that followed 40-odd Bulgarians making monkey noises. Our hypocrisy over racism has reached ridiculous levels.
description: The two former managers were speaking on Sky Sports after Liverpool's 1-1 draw with Manchester United
